title: How to Repair a Backhoe Tire

steps.headline: Ensure safety first.
steps.description: Always support any vehicle safely when removing or installing wheels. If possible, get a helper. Tractor tires are heavy to work with. If you're able, get assistance. Be conscious at all times that pry bars can slip and cause serious injury. Use with great care.

steps.headline: Lift the tire off of the ground.
steps.description: On a backhoe, the stabilizer can be used for this job on rear tires, or the loader bucket for front wheels.

steps.headline: Remove the lug bolts.
steps.description: Using a pneumatic impact wrench can speed up this process.

steps.headline: Remove the wheel from the tractor, lay it down on level ground (if possible), and remove valve stem core to fully deflate the tire.
Press the tire off the wheel inner rim bead so it can be taken off.
steps.description: With a backhoe, you may be able to complete this step with the digging bucket. If necessary, use a tire hammer to break the tire's bead loose.

steps.headline: Flip the tire over and break the bead loose on the outside of the wheel.
Place a support on the side of the tire.
steps.description: Use a wood block so the tire will rise up from the rim as it's pried off.

steps.headline: Use a tire iron or a pry bar to pry the tire's bead off the rim.
steps.description: Start near the valve stem and work around the tire, heading away from the stem to keep from pinching it.

steps.headline: Continue to work around the tire until the whole tire is pried off the rim.
steps.description: Then block the tire up higher so the tube (if the tire has a tube) can be removed.

steps.headline: Remove the valve stem and stem locknut from the tube.
Pull the tube out of the wheel beginning at the valve stem and working around the rim.
Place the tube on top of the tire so it is in the same position it was in when it was inside the tire.
steps.description: This will allow you to look for problems with the tire itself when you locate the leak in the tube.

steps.headline: Replace the valve stem and inflate the tube so you can look for the leak.
steps.description: Using a spray bottle with soapy water will help you find small punctures, but obvious damage may not require this technique.

steps.headline: Deflate tube and place it on a comfortable, flat working surface.
steps.description: A truck tailgate or a worktable is good for this.

steps.headline: Get out (or go purchase) your patch kit.
steps.description: Make sure you know exactly where the damaged spot on the tire is, then buff an area with a buffing tool to roughen up the rubber. Work around the puncture or damaged location so the patch will fit within the roughened area.

steps.headline: Apply rubber cement to the area you've buffed, then wipe off the excess glue.
steps.description: Allow it to dry until it's no longer glossy. Do not wait too long to apply the patch, or the glue may dry completely and lose its adhesion.

steps.headline: Peel the patch backing material off the patch.
steps.description: Take care not to touch the surface of the patch underneath it.

steps.headline: Place the patch over the damaged spot on the tube, being careful not to allow it to wrinkle.
steps.description: Push the patch or roll it with a patch roller to make sure it's well bonded to the tube.

steps.headline: Check the sidewall near the location where the tube was damaged before replacing the tube.
steps.description: You may find an old nail, wood splinter or other object still embedded in the tire, or you could see a damaged area that will need attention before replacing the tube.

steps.headline: Install a boot on any large holes or split sidewall areas of the tire.
steps.description: This will prevent the tube from being damaged when the tire is reinflated.

steps.headline: Reinstall the tube in the tire.
steps.description: Make sure the valve stem is aligned with the hole in the rim where it will fit. Push the valve stem through the hole made of it, and replace the retaining nut that will hold it in place as the tire is remounted on the rim.

steps.headline: Use your tire tool or pry bars to pull the tire back onto the rim.
steps.description: Start near, but not directly in line with, the valve stem, then work around the rim moving away from the valve stem to prevent pinching the tube. Continue around the tire until it is reinstalled completely on the rim.

steps.headline: Replace the valve stem core and inflate the tire.
steps.description: You will hear air escaping from the cavity between the tube and tire as the tube inflates, but don't worry about it, as this is normal.

steps.headline: Make sure the tire's bead is in line with the edge of the rim as the air pressure forces the bead into place on the rim.
steps.description: This will help prevent a blow-off, where the air pressure might accidentally blow a part of the tire off the wheel assembly.

steps.headline: Lift the tire back up and roll it close to the axle hub where it will be mounted.
steps.description: Adjust the height of the tire so the wheel will fit the hub, then align the lug bolt holds and install the lug bolts.

steps.headline: Tighten the lug bolts securely.
steps.description: To make sure the wheel fits the hub properly, criss-cross the hub tightening bolts across from each other rather than working a circular pattern.

steps.headline: Check the tire pressure with a gauge.
steps.description: Let the tire back on the ground, and clean up your tools.
